Description: An unclothed upper part of a man, slightly grotesque, with short curly hair, wearing a garland round his neck; his arms are largely lost, but the left is extended. The vertebrae are well indicated at the rear, and he appears to have Pott's Disease (tuberculosis of the spine). There is a large split across the back. Hollow; two-piece mould, the garland applied separately. Micaceous brown Nile silt with a thick grey core. Painted red overall, except on hair.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Ptolemaic, second or first century BC. For a brief discussion of Pott's Disease (tuberculosis of the spine), see Grmek and Gourevitch 1998: 217–19.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3185)
Condition: incomplete - head and upper torso only
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
